channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Taliban announce new government for Afghanistan
item.description: After naming its cabinet ministers, the group declared that Afghanistan is now an "Islamic emirate".

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban fire warning shots at protest in Kabul
item.description: Unrest grows as more Afghans demand women's rights and chant anti-Taliban and anti-Pakistan slogans.

item.title: Brazil on edge as Bolsonaro supporters march on Congress
item.description: Police are guarding the Supreme Court amid warnings that the president's supporters may try to storm it.

item.title: Spanish woman sues after DNA test reveals birth swap error
item.description: Health authorities admit the woman was mistakenly switched with another baby at a hospital in 2002.

item.title: Fear and excitement in El Salvador as Bitcoin becomes legal tender
item.description: Millions of Salvadorians are expected to download a digital wallet app with $30 of free Bitcoin.

item.title: Chinese social media site Weibo suspends 22 K-pop accounts
item.description: The social media site says 22 fan accounts have been suspended for "irrational celebrity support”.

item.title: Ethiopia's Tigray crisis: TPLF says 150 have died of starvation
item.description: There is a "complete depletion of food stocks" in the Ethiopian region of Tigray, the TPLF says.

item.title: German election: Merkel attacks left as polls point to defeat
item.description: The German chancellor targets the centre-left favourite to succeed her, ahead of September elections.

item.title: Saipul Jamil: Row over sex offender appearing on Indonesian TV
item.description: A petition asking to keep Saipul Jamil off TV screens has been signed by nearly 500,000 people.

item.title: Texas abortion clinics will be protected, Justice Department says
item.description: US Justice Department's pledge comes after a near-total ban on abortions took effect in the state.

item.title: Justin Trudeau hit by stones on campaign trail
item.description: The Canadian leader's campaign has been disrupted by protesters angry at a planned vaccine mandate.

item.title: Audio of Ripper the 'talking' Australian duck rediscovered
item.description: The 1987 recording appears to show Ripper the Australian musk duck saying: "You bloody fool".

item.title: The Taliban embrace social media: 'We too want to change perceptions'
item.description: Famed for their shunning of technology, the Taliban are realising they need to be on social media too.

item.title: Nizar Banat: The death shaking the Palestinian leadership
item.description: The killing of Nizar Banat in Palestinian custody has fuelled rare protests calling for change.

item.title: India jewellery ad starring trans model wins hearts
item.description: The ad is being praised in India where popular culture still portrays transgender people as caricatures.

item.title: The South African farm turning flies into food for pets - and maybe people
item.description: A South African company is aiming to take advantage of a new interest in protein-rich insects.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Sebastian Vettel on speaking out as an LGBTQ+ ally: 'Everyone has the same right to love'
item.description: Sebastian Vettel made headlines at the Hungarian Grand Prix by wearing a T-shirt in support of LGBTQ+ rights. He tells the BBC's LGBT Sport Podcast why he is taking a stand.

item.title: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed: How '9/11 mastermind' slipped through FBI's fingers
item.description: Could the man accused of hatching the plot to fly planes into US landmarks 20 years ago have been stopped?

item.title: Taliban fire shots to disperse protest in Kabul
item.description: Hundreds of protesters took to the streets on Tuesday to demand women's rights and denounce Taliban rule.

item.title: Australian bush rescue: Mother's reunion with boy lost for four days
item.description: Three-year-old Anthony "AJ" Elfalak is recovering with family after going missing for four days.

item.title: Mexico: Flash flooding sweeps away cars after heavy rain
item.description: Heavy rain in central Mexico sparked flash floods in Ecatepec and Nexahualcóyotl.

item.title: Esports: Why are there so few professional women gamers?
item.description: There are no female players in the top 300 earners in esports, according to research shared with BBC News.

item.title: Israeli conjoined twins see each other for first time after surgery
item.description: The Israeli twin girls were joined at the head but have been separated after a rare operation.

item.title: Afghanistan: The pledge binding al-Qaeda to the Taliban
item.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".

item.title: Afghanistan: Rural areas welcome peace and end of war
item.description: In more rural areas of Afghanistan, people welcome the end of a war that has killed tens of thousands.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.
